messages: 00f8648b773bd453ee1d8e5cf37d790e (02:00): noodl: got it ?

03eb466d3550e4f45e32f77537f4c6bc (02:00): noodl, sounds cool. I may actually try that out some time. Actually there are only a few people taking this class (including myself) that will even really be using PHP and CGI stuff, the rest of them are learning to make sites in Dreamweaver...
1b70f328e83584318ab35ff5c7c96056 (02:01): ANOMIS: Where did www/www.php some from? Is that random?
5285b19c5d644bdc942ed3681d3f794b (02:01): noodle: but can I force it serverside? regardless what client want? :)
00f8648b773bd453ee1d8e5cf37d790e (02:01): noodl: no.. it's my stuff

03eb466d3550e4f45e32f77537f4c6bc (02:01): Just need to make sure that the server is secure; during the time that I have been working on the server at least 10 people so far have asked me to "hack into the internet" for them.

1b70f328e83584318ab35ff5c7c96056 (02:02): ANOMIS: Ok, you'll need a couple of RewriteConds, one for %{HTTP_HOST} and another for %{QUERY_STRING}. Have a go with using those in the rewrite target if you like. Ask again if that doesn't work out.
03eb466d3550e4f45e32f77537f4c6bc (02:02): Don't even want to think what what would happen if one of these punks downloaded something made my someone who actually knew what they were doing.
00f8648b773bd453ee1d8e5cf37d790e (02:03): what regex do i need to use ? :)
03eb466d3550e4f45e32f77537f4c6bc (02:03): Anyway, thanks for the help. I will have to do that tomorrow while I am working on it. Bye.
1b70f328e83584318ab35ff5c7c96056 (02:04): Grundee: hehe. yeah, securing a shared web host on unix is a tricky business. that article explains one method with php as fastcgi + suexec.
1b70f328e83584318ab35ff5c7c96056 (02:08): ANOMIS: Something like RewriteCond %{HTTP_HOST} (.+) // RewriteCond %{QUERY_STRING} (.+) // RewriteRule (.+) http://%1/$1?%2
00f8648b773bd453ee1d8e5cf37d790e (02:08): cool, thanks, i'll try messing with it:)
00f8648b773bd453ee1d8e5cf37d790e (02:08): now if there is an auth for the www dir, it will go into effect with the rewrite, yes?
00f8648b773bd453ee1d8e5cf37d790e (02:08): (while the other site wont be effect if no ?blah) ?
1b70f328e83584318ab35ff5c7c96056 (02:10): ANOMIS: hopefully you're not trying this with a .htaccess file, or auth will get rather tricky.
5285b19c5d644bdc942ed3681d3f794b (02:14): noodl? is there a way to force lower value?
1b70f328e83584318ab35ff5c7c96056 (02:15): Apache will ignore a request for a long keep-alive of course. As for php, who knows. It gets imaginative at times..

4ce434b52c7582ece7dc214cf37ae23b (02:50): programatically, without knowing it beforehand

1b70f328e83584318ab35ff5c7c96056 (02:50): kiliko: Your <VirtualHost name:80> stanzas are wrong.. Using a name in <VirtualHost is discouraged. Better to use <VirtualHost *:80> instead and let ServerName deal with name recognition.
35a8b89f6e90cc31ac4005aa592c7251 (02:51): noodl, sould i remove NameVirtualHost ?

c9ecae996ff8795e1651474588aa852a (02:54): Hey guys. Got any tips for setting up VirtualHosts? I have a couple created in a .conf file (being linked by an Include, preset in Apache) and the first Host on the list works, but no matter which domain I go to, it always comes up. Any ideas how to make it so each host points in the right folder? Also, I commented out most of the stuff in the httpd.conf, so there really isn't anything driving the server aside from the VirtualHosts.. at lea

1b70f328e83584318ab35ff5c7c96056 (02:54): kiliko: If you have a consistent NameVirtualHost *:80 for the non-ssl vhosts, it doesn't need to be part of your macro. Still, it needs to be specified at least once.
a70e134b2395b3b432ddec08d347d582 (02:55): I can't get on the efnet network
a70e134b2395b3b432ddec08d347d582 (02:55): irc.choopa.ner
1b70f328e83584318ab35ff5c7c96056 (02:55): mrbojangles: See:

b0a90be919a9f920bb8ad2caca4e91f0 (02:55): The value of a NameVirtualHost directive has to match the content of <VirtualHost> exactly. For example, NameVirtualHost *:80 must be used with <VirtualHost *:80>
1b70f328e83584318ab35ff5c7c96056 (02:55): Same for kiliko ^^
c9ecae996ff8795e1651474588aa852a (02:56): Do you need a NameVirtualHost for each VirtualHost?
35a8b89f6e90cc31ac4005aa592c7251 (02:57): hmmm, i get this now [warn] _default_ VirtualHost overlap on port 443, the first has precedence
1b70f328e83584318ab35ff5c7c96056 (02:58): kiliko: You know that name based vhosts don't work with ssl, right?
1b70f328e83584318ab35ff5c7c96056 (02:58): Well, they do, but not without ssl warnings.
1b70f328e83584318ab35ff5c7c96056 (02:58): Read the onlamp article here:

b0a90be919a9f920bb8ad2caca4e91f0 (02:58): When using SSL, each virtual host must have either its own IP address or its own port. Or both. or for details see http://httpd.apache.org/docs-2.0/ssl/ssl_faq.html#vhosts2 or http://www.onlamp.com/pub/a/apache/2005/02/17/apacheckbk.html or see SNI or consider wildcard certificates or
b0a90be919a9f920bb8ad2caca4e91f0 (02:58): ..http://wiki.cacert.org/wiki/VhostTaskForce or see ip based vhosts

35a8b89f6e90cc31ac4005aa592c7251 (03:06): noodl, this is annoying, if i do as i did befor with mod_macro i had no problem with haveing more then one site with ssl support. -- http://apache.pastebin.ca/183407
